stem: A 29-year-old client with bipolar disorder is admitted with severe vomiting, ataxia (stumbling), and hand tremors. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
SITUATION: 29-year-old with bipolar disorder admitted at 14:30 for acute mental status changes and GI distress.

BACKGROUND: Client has been taking lithium carbonate for 2 years. The client recently took ibuprofen for back pain and reduced fluid intake due to a 'stomach bug.'

ASSESSMENT: The client exhibits an unsteady gait, slurred speech, and coarse tremors in both hands. Serum lithium is 2.6 mEq/L, serum sodium is 132 mEq/L, and creatinine is 1.9 mg/dL.

RECOMMENDATION: Recommend immediate cessation of lithium, IV fluid resuscitation with 0.9% normal saline, continuous cardiac monitoring, and possible hemodialysis if the client's condition deteriorates or lithium levels remain critically high.

tabs.content:

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content:
HR: 110 bpm
BP: 90/60 mmHg
RR: 24 breaths/min
SpO2: 96% on room air

tabs.title: Neuro Assessment
tabs.content: Presence of coarse tremors. Ataxic gait (positive Romberg). Confusion to time and place.

actionOptions.text: Immediately hold all scheduled doses of lithium
Initiate IV 0.9% normal saline at 150 mL/hr
Administer an extra dose of sodium polystyrene sulfonate (Kayexalate)
Administer diazepam for alcohol withdrawal prevention

parameterOptions.text: Serial serum lithium and creatinine levels
Lithium dose timing and peak flow meter

rationale.correct: The client is experiencing acute lithium toxicity (c2) with a critical level of 2.6 mEq/L. Symptoms include coarse tremors, ataxia, and slurred speech. Risk factors include hyponatremia (Na 132 mEq/L) and NSAID use (ibuprofen), both of which decrease renal clearance of lithium, leading to increased serum levels. Priority actions include immediately holding all scheduled doses of lithium (a1) to prevent further accumulation and initiating IV 0.9% normal saline at 150 mL/hr (a2) to promote lithium excretion through the kidneys. Monitoring serial serum lithium and creatinine levels (p1) is crucial to assess the effectiveness of treatment and renal function. Neurological status and gait stability (p2) should be closely monitored to detect any worsening of neurological symptoms.
clinicalPearls: Lithium toxicity is exacerbated by dehydration, sodium depletion, and impaired renal function.
NSAIDs, ACE inhibitors, and thiazide diuretics can elevate lithium levels.
Severe lithium toxicity (levels >2.5 mEq/L) may require hemodialysis to remove lithium from the body.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Kayexalate is used to treat hyperkalemia, not lithium toxicity. The priority is to enhance lithium excretion and prevent further absorption.

mnemonic.title: Lithium Toxicity Signs
mnemonic.expansion: N - Neuro: Tremors, confusion, ataxia.  A - Acute Kidney Injury.  S - Sodium low. T - Thirst/dehydration. Y - 'Yikes!' - This is an emergency!
